item.title: Free Consultation
item.description: I offer one free consultation (over video or phone) to understand how we could work together. Please contact me at janani@riselife.org to setup an appointment.

item.title: Talks and Workshops
item.description: I give talks and conduct workshops about preventive health at companies and gatherings. To book an engagement, please contact me at janani@riselife.org.

item.title: Mind Body Connection: Considering the Evidence
item.description: The following video contains a wealth of information on mindbody health with an emphasis on cardiovascular health (the speaker, Dr James Kneller, is a cardiologist).

item.title: Cool down with Sheetali Breathing
item.description: Many more people practice Kapalabhati, the breath of fire, than Sheetali, the cooling breath. Sheetal means cool and soothing in Sanskrit and that is the effect it has on the mind and body.

item.title: Publications
item.description: https://www.themindfulword.org/2017/breathe-live-yoga-practice/ Living Fearlessly: Building inner strength through self-reflection

item.title: Trāṭaka
item.description: Meditation is becoming very popular nowadays but it is mainly mindfulness which is getting a lot of the attention. Trāṭaka is a less known type of meditation which appears in stories such as ‘The Monk who Sold his Ferrari’ by Rabin Sharma and ‘The Wonderful Story of Henry Sugar’ by Roald Dahl.

item.title: What’s wrong with the Western Medical System
item.description: Western medicine has done wonders for humanity. It plays a very important role in saving lives in emergencies, uses the best technology available to diagnose people’s health issues and bases much of it’s progress on medical and scientific research.

item.title: Introduction to Pranayama
item.description: Prana can be translated to mean breath, though in subtle terms it is also associated with ‘life force’, ‘vital energy’. Ayama means control. Together, Pranayama means control of breath.

item.title: The Benefits of Meditation
item.description: The claim that meditation is good for you and can help improve or enhance one’s mental and physical health is quite a remarkable claim. How can sitting still and paying attention to one’s breath have such an enormous impact on so many conditions we suffer from?

item.title: What does it mean to be healthy?
item.description: When I ask people asked what they think it means to be healthy, I often get responses like: “It’s when you’re not sick” “To be fit” “When all your parts are working properly” These definitions seem focused on one’s physical body and see health as a state in which going to a doctor is not necessary.

item.title: Testimonials
item.description: “Thank you, Janani! The breathing exercises you taught me really helped me stay calm during my maths exam. I didn’t go blank as I always do.

item.title: What I Do
item.description: Wellness Speaker I speak about Preventive Health and conduct workshops (both online and in-person) at Companies Schools Libraries Religious & Community Centers Retirement Communities Private parties/gatherings Some examples of topics include

item.title: Who I Am
item.description: Dr. Janani Dhinakaran is a Wellness Speaker and Health Coach. She is the Program Director at Whole Brain Health Initiative and the author of Living Fearlessly: Building inner strength through self-reflection.
